titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to The Tony Judt Collection MC 233
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Katie Ehrlich.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2015-05-04T16:28-0400

did.abstract: The Tony Judt Collection contains research, notes, correspondence, and other material related his work as a professor and essayist. The collection spans the start of his teaching career in 1976, to his death in 2010, with heavy focus on the 1990s and 2000s.

physdesc.label: General Physical Description note
physdesc.extent: (26 Paige boxes, 1 manuscript box, 2 index card file boxes, 1 flat box)

processinfo.head: Processing Note
processinfo.p: Original order was not always present but was maintained where possible. Most of the material related to Postwar was filed and housed together prior to processing, while correspondence, material from Judt's lectures, classes and other books were somewhat scattered.
Administrative files, student files and much of the correspondence had their own filing system and likely came from the Remarque Institute offices. The order of these files was maintained.

The folder titles Judt created were retained throughout the collection when possible. However, many titles lacked sufficient information and some did not match the folder contents. In these cases, additional detail was added. In other cases, loose material was integrated into the proper series and/or subseries, where discernible, and given folder titles.
See notes at the series level for additional details.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection is separated into 10 series, loosely arranged by Judt's type of work. Several series are further divided because of the manner in which the material was originally filed or because of their breadth. See series and subseries notes for further explication.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Tony Robert Judt was a historian, essayist and public intellectual. He established the Remarque Institute at New York University and served as its first director. He taught at NYU from 1987 until his death from amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) in 2010. Judt focused on French intellectual and 20th century European affairs in his teaching and writing, both academic and popular. He is perhaps best known for his 800-plus page history of Europe, Postwar.

Judt was born in London in 1948 to a middle class secular Jewish family with Eastern European roots. He spent his later teen years in Israel, volunteering as an interpreter during the Six-Day War. Judt later became disillusioned by the Zionist movement and left-wing politics. Later, he often wrote about this ideological change in the context of his identification with social democracy.

After Israel, Judt returned to Europe to study and received degrees in history from the University of Cambridge as well as École Normale Supérieure in Paris. He taught at Cambridge, University of California, Davis, University of California, Berkeley, and University of Oxford before coming to NYU. For a time in the 1980s, Judt lived in Prague and Vienna where he witnessed the political transformations of the time and became more focused on Eastern Europe in his studies and teaching.

Judt began his tenure at NYU as a professor in the Department of History. He taught at the Institute of French Studies as well, briefly serving as director in 1989. He also chaired the Department of History (1992-1993) and served as Dean for the Humanities, Faculty of Arts and Science (1993-1995). In 2006, Judt was given the title University Professor, “a rank conferred upon outstanding NYU faculty whose scholarship extends across traditional disciplinary boundaries and who are internationally recognized scholars and teachers.”

In 1992, Judt was appointed to the Erich Maria Remarque Chair in European Studies and helped establish the Remarque Institute three years later. The Institute’s purpose is to “support and promote the study of Europe and to encourage and facilitate communication between Americans and Europeans.” Remarque’s widow, Paulette Goddard, bequeathed funding for the creation of the Institute. Remarque offers fellowships and hosts programs, lectures, seminars and other events.

Judt authored and edited numerous books, 13 of which are represented in this collection. His work in French socialism and intellectual history is reflected in his earlier books including Socialism in Provence (1979), Marxism and the French Left (1979), Past Imperfect: French Intellectuals, 1944-1956 (1992), and Burden of Responsibility: Blum, Camus, Aron, and the French Twentieth Century (1998).

Throughout his career at NYU, Judt wrote prolifically for outlets such as The New York Review of Books, The New York Times and The National Review, often tying current events to history. He weighed in heavily on the September 11 terrorist attacks, war in Iraq, and matters in American and European policy. He wrote for academic journals, as well. In 2008, Foreign Policy magazine named him one of the top 100 public intellectuals. Judt won the George Orwell Special Prize for Lifetime Achievement in 2009.

Considered a public intellectual by many, Judt always said he thought of himself as a teacher first. In 2003, he was criticized for his New York Review of Books article entitled “Israel: The Alternative,” in which he described the country as an “anachronism” and proposed a bi-national one-state solution. In 2006, two lectures he was set to give on the topic were canceled due to complaints from Jewish groups over his stance on Israel. A public discussion in the press followed.

Postwar, published in 2005, was the culmination of more than a decade of research and thought. It was Judt’s last work of original historical research that he was able to physically complete himself, due to his illness. In 2008, he published a collection of essays that had mostly appeared in New York Review of Books entitled Reappraisals: Reflections on the Forgotten Twentieth Century. Later that year, he was diagnosed with ALS, but continued writing with the help of assistants to transcribe. He wrote about his illness and turned more toward autobiographical essay writing in the final years of his life, dictating many articles.

In October 2009, bound to a wheelchair and connected to a breathing apparatus, Judt delivered the annual Remarque Institute Lecture, his last public lecture, to an audience at NYU. He delivered it from memory. The lecture, entitled “What is Living and What is Dead in Social Democracy” was turned into the book Ill Fares the Land. Another book of Judt’s previously published essays, The Memory Chalet, was published in 2010. It contains a mix of personal and historical essays. The final book of Judt's writing, Thinking the Twentieth Century, was adapted from Judt’s conversations with colleague Timothy Snyder about his life, intellectual journey, and work just prior to his death. It was published posthumously in 2012.
Judt died August 6, 2010. He had two children with wife Jennifer Homans—Daniel and Nicholas.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Published citations should take the following form:
Identification of item, date (if known); The Tony Judt Collection; MC 233; Box number; folder number; New York University Archives

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection contains research, notes, correspondence, and other material related to Tony Judt's work as a professor, essayist and historian. The collection spans the start of his career in 1976, to his death in 2010, with heavy focus on the 1990s and 2000s.

Nearly half of the collection consists of research material and notes for Judt's books, namely Postwar. There is little material related to his personal life. Approximately one-quarter is research and notes for articles published in periodicals such as The New York Review of Books and Times Literary Supplement. The correspondence in the collection mostly comes from readers and colleagues, often commenting on his work.

Judt's teaching files are also represented and contain syllabi, reading lists and lecture notes. There are also administrative files from Judt's tenure as director of the Remarque Institute, but those are subject to a 20-year restriction period.
See notes at the series level for additional details.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection is currently closed to researchers.

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: The material in this collection originated from Judt's office at the Remarque Institute and his home. A significant portion was appraised and inventoried by a private party in 2011. The collection arrived at the University Archives in 2013.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The material in this series is organized by the title to which it relates, and then typically chronologically within each subseries.

Subseries A: La Reconstruction du Parti Socialiste (1976)
Subseries B: Socialism in Provence, 1871-1914 (1979)
Subseries C: Marxism and the French Left (1986)
Subseries D: Resistance and Revolution in Mediterranean Europe, 1939-1948 (1989)
Subseries E: Past imperfect: French intellectuals, 1944-1956 (1992)
Subseries F: A Grand Illusion? An Essay on Europe (1996)
Subseries G: Burden of Responsibility (1998)
Subseries H: The Politics of Retribution in Europe: World War II and Its Aftermath (2000)
Subseries I: Postwar (2005)
Subseries J: Reappraisals (2008)
Subseries K: Thinking the Twentieth Century (2012)
Subseries L: Ill Fares the Land (2010)
Subseries M: The Memory Chalet (2010)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains notes, research, drafts and reviews related to the books Judt authored throughout his career.

The bulk of the material in this series is from Postwar. There are also notes and research related to Past Imperfect, A Grand Illusion?, and Burden of Responsibility. Judt's papers contained drafts of essay collections he titled "Israel Book," "State of Exception" and "Essays." All of these appear to be alternative titles for Reappraisals.
The subseries also contain reviews and correspondence related to each of Judt's works. Correspondence from readers can also be found in Series VII: Correspondence.

did.unittitle: Subseries A: La Reconstruction du Parti Socialiste (1976)
Subseries C: Marxism and the French Left (1986)
Subseries D: Resistance and Revolution in Mediterranean Europe, 1939-1948 (1989)
Subseries E: Past imperfect: French intellectuals, 1944-1956 (1992)
Subseries F: A Grand Illusion? An Essay on Europe (1996)
Subseries H: The Politics of Retribution in Europe: World War II and Its Aftermath (2000)

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This subseries is further divided to reflect Judt's writing process. His research and notes from Postwar appear in the collection in several groupings that were brought together during processing. These include sets of notes organized by an outline system, as well as by chapter and subject. The way Judt organized his notes is not necessarily reflected in the published version of the book.

Sub-subseries i: Outline Notes
Sub-subseries ii: Subject Notes
Sub-subseries iii: Chapter Notes
Sub-subseries iv: Other Notes and Drafts
Sub-subseries v: Master Set 1st Madeup - Author's Galleys
Sub-subseries vi: Author's correx to final pass
Sub-subseries vii: "Setting MS" manuscript
Sub-subseries viii: Press, reviews, correspondence

processinfo.head: Processing Note
processinfo.p: Several folders in this grouping were left empty. The titles of these folders have been retained here and noted as such.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is divided into two subseries. Reprints of Judt's articles have been separated from his notes and other source material for articles. The articles are arranged chronologically by publication year.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series is comprised primarily of the notes, research, drafts and correspondence related to articles and essays published in a variety of outlets. While this series is extensive in the number of Judt's articles it covers, for some of these works, only photocopies can be found in the collection.

The following abbreviations are used to denote publication titles:
FT - Financial Times
LRB - London Review of Books
NYR - New York Review of Books
NYT - New York Times
TLS - Times Literary Supplement
TNR - The New Republic

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: All efforts were made to associate all of Judt's notes to a piece of work, as many were unfiled or filed in vaguely titled folders.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains research files that did not appear to be connected to any of Judt's specific works. Many of the folder titles are Judt's, but some material was loose or unlabeled and so new folder titles were created. These files contain annotated clippings, printouts and photocopies of articles. There are also annotated typescripts and other loose documents not written by Judt.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series is separated into two subseries.
Subseries A: Class Material contains syllabi, readings and reading lists, and lecture notes from throughout Judt's teaching career. This material was culled from all over the collection.
Subseries B: Student Files was a pre-existing grouping of files, so original order was maintained here and placed in Series IV: Teaching Files.

processinfo.head: Processing Note
processinfo.p: This series contained photocopies of readings for classes Judt taught. Readings not annotated by Judt were discarded and their bibliographic information is included below with reference to the folder they were originally filed in.

odd.head: History of Socialism and Communism (1983)
odd.p: Fourier, Charles. Part II: Chapters II-IV in The Harmonian Man: Selected Writings of Charles Fourier, edited by Mark Poster. (Garden City, N.Y.: Doubleday, 1971)
Saint-Simon, Claude-Henri de. Chapter VIII-IX in The Political Thought of Saint-Simon, edited by Ghița Ionescu. (London: Oxford University Press, 1976).
Tristan, Flora. “To Working Men and Women,” Chapters I-IV in The Workers’ Union. (Paris: 1843).

odd.head: Photocopies

Dworkin, Ronald. “Reverse Discrimination” in Taking Rights Seriously.

Locke, John. Chapter V-VI in The Second Treatise of Government.
MacIntyre, Alasdair. “Is a Science of Comparative Politics Possible?” In Against the Self-Images of the Ages: Essays on Ideology and Philosophy. (Notre Dame, Ind.: University of Notre Dame, 1978).
Mill, John Stuart. “On Liberty: Of the Liberty of Thought and Discussion” in Three Essays.
Raphael, David Daiches. “Grounds of Political Obligation” in Problems of Political Philosophy.
Rawls, John. “Justice as Fairness,” in Philosophy, Politics and Society, edited by Peter Laslett and W.G. Runciman. (Oxford: Basil Blackwell, 1972)
Rousseau, Jean-Jacques. Book II, Chapter I-XI in The Social Contract.
Thomson, J.J. “A Defence of Abortion” in The Philosophy of Law, edited by R.M. Dworkin. (Oxford: Oxford Univerity Press, 1977)
Williams, Bernard. “The Idea of Equality” in Philosophy, Politics and Society, edited by Peter Laslett and W.G. Runciman. (Oxford: Basil Blackwell, 1972)

odd.head: Loose Material

odd.head: General Note
odd.p: Discarded - un-annotated copy of Dombrowski Risser, Nicole, France Under Fire: German Invasion, Civilian Flight and Family Survival during World War II, 1940-44

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The material in this series is arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains material related to Judt's speaking engagements outside of his teaching duties, including notes, outlines and drafts as well as research material. In most cases, the folder contents were clear from their titles. Elsewhere, folder titles were created according to the title of the lecture of where the speech was given.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Administrative records are closed for 20 years after their date of creation.
Contact the University Archives for details.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Subseries A is organized alphabetically by given and created folder titles.
Subseries B is organized alphabetically by correspondent.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series is separated into two subseries.

Subseries A: Chronological, Misc. contains correspondence from throughout the collection. There was some pre-existing order to the material, but much of it was scattered and brought together into one series.
Subseries B: By Correspondent was a pre-existing grouping of files, titled "Colleagues." Original order was maintained here and the material was placed within this series.

did.unittitle: NEH evaluation for Eastern Europe book

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains articles written about Judt over the course of his career. Some are original clippings, while others are online versions printed out years later. Many are from European news outlets and are not in English.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The University Archives cannot currently provide access to the material in this series. Please contact the Archives for further information.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series was pulled together from different parts of the collection, mostly from the Remarque Institute administrative files. Material includes floppy disks of Judt's work, recordings of Remarque Institute Lectures, and assorted CDs and DVDs sent to Judt.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains two boxes of 3x5 index cards with bibliographic information on primary and secondary source material filed topically. It is unclear whether the cards are tied to any specific work of Judt's or whether they comprise more of a general file he kept. Each entry in this series denotes titles on dividers within the index card boxes.
